conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the suitcase when it is pulled with an oblique upward force. We are given the mass of the suitcase, the minimum pulling force, the angle of the pull, and the gravitational acceleration. We need to find the coefficient of friction (μ) and the angle (θ) at which the suitcase is pulled.
The suitcase can be either pushed or pulled on the ground.
The total mass of the suitcase is 15 kg, and the gravitational acceleration is g = 10 m/s².
The minimum value of the pull is 90 N, and the angle between the pull and the horizontal direction is θ.
The resistance of the suitcase to the ground is proportional to the supporting force of the ground, with the ratio being μ.
The suitcase has a handle and wheels.

premise: The weight of the suitcase (W) acting downward: W = mg = 15 kg * 10 m/s² = 150 N
conclusion: The weight of the suitcase is 150 N.

premise: The normal force (N) acts upward, perpendicular to the ground.
conclusion: The normal force is perpendicular to the ground.

premise: The pulling force (F) acts at an angle θ with the horizontal.
conclusion: The pulling force acts at an angle θ with the horizontal.

premise: The frictional force (f) acts opposite to the direction of motion.
conclusion: The frictional force acts opposite to the direction of motion.

premise: Resolving the pulling force (F) into components: Horizontal component: Fcosθ, Vertical component: Fsinθ
conclusion: The horizontal component of the pulling force is Fcosθ, and the vertical component is Fsinθ.

premise: Equilibrium conditions: In the vertical direction: N + Fsinθ = W
conclusion: In the vertical direction, N + Fsinθ = W.

premise: Equilibrium conditions: In the horizontal direction: Fcosθ = f
conclusion: In the horizontal direction, Fcosθ = f.
The frictional force is f = μN.

premise: Substituting the values: N = W - Fsinθ = 150 N - 90 N * sinθ
f = μN = μ(150 N - 90 N * sinθ)
